I'm incredibly disappointed by this vote. Under the Affordable Care Act, the number of uninsured Americans has been cut in half as millions gained access to healthcare – many for the first time. It also has meant that no one can be denied care for a pre-existing condition. Furthermore, the ACA has held the rise in health care costs to the slowest rate in 50 years.   Yet despite the lives changed and saved, Republicans today moved forward with their plan to repeal this popular law, without any substantial proposal to replace it. This would be a disaster. Even the American Medical Association recently warned of the catastrophic impacts of the Republicans’ politically motivated repeal of the ACA.   Now that Republicans are poised to take control of both Congress and the White House, they have a responsibility to put forward a coherent plan for the American people that will let sick individuals keep their care, keep costs low, and prevent past injustices like the large discrepancy in costs for men and women. However, none of these priorities were discussed in the Republicans’ march to repeal the ACA.   It’s time to stop running against Democrats and to start showing Americans how you can help them.

Seventy-five years ago today, President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066, which led to the incarceration of over 120,000 individuals based solely on their Japanese ancestry. Wartime hysteria, prejudice, and a lack of political leadership led to one of the most shameful periods in our nation’s history, where American citizens were targeted based solely on their ethnicity and stripped of their basic civil rights without any due process. These violations were so unconscionable that Congress later apologized for it. But sadly, there are new demagogues who want to repeat this dark chapter.  Seventy-five years later, we once again have a President signing Executive Orders steeped in xenophobia and racism. Even worse, there are now individuals who have gone so far as to cite Japanese American internment as a precedent for these actions. This is unacceptable. So as we observe this year’s Day of Remembrance, let us recommit ourselves to rejecting prejudice and protecting the civil liberties of all Americans. We will not allow history to repeat itself.

I’d like to introduce you to Arcadia’s Tiffany Hu, the winner of this year’s Artistic Discovery Competition. This is a competition held every year for students in each Congressional District. The winners have their art displayed in the halls of the Capitol for a year. Tiffany’s piece, entitled “Different Beauty”, was inspired by how different standards of beauty differ across the world. As she researched and learned more, Tiffany decided to paint a depiction of four distinct women with very different standards of beauty. The first woman is from the U.S., with plastic surgery markings dotted across her face. The second woman is from the indigenous Maori people in New Zealand, where women tattoo their chins to symbolize their growth into adulthood. The third woman is from India, where intricate henna tattoos are commonly used in weddings and ceremonies. The last woman is from the Middle East, and Tiffany wanted the audience to focus on the eyes, because women who cover their faces often use eyeliner to make their eyes more noticeable. Lastly, she placed all four images on one bust as an example of the way women are objectified across societies. Yet, despite this objectification and the societal challenges placed on women, each of these four women exudes a clear sense of strength that reminds the audience that each woman is different but that all women are beautiful.

Three days later, he underwent brain surgery which is followed up by radiosurgey (radiation treatment) about a month later.  This was hundreds of thousands of dollars for the surgery and the radiation treatment. Fortunately, he had good insurance, but before the ACA, he would have had to kick in his copay for service for the whole amount. But the ACA put a cap on out of pocket expenses.  A fellow co-worker of Charles' who recently passed away from his brain tumor first came down with it before the ACA.  His treatment costs bankrupted him.   If the Republican plan passes, Charles now has a pre-existing condition that can mean he is denied coverage. We can't let that happen.
